awd_titl_txt: Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
According to the 2015 Women in Manufacturing Study, women comprise 47% of the total United States labor force, but hold only 27% of manufacturing jobs.  The Skills Gap in US Manufacturing estimates that six of every ten manufacturing jobs are unfilled because of a shortage of qualified applicants.  One approach to increasing the labor pool for the critical manufacturing sector of the US economy may be to recruit more women into the field.  This project aims to achieve this goal by implementing model practices to recruit and retain underrepresented groups, particularly females, in manufacturing education programs and employment.  It will implement an apprenticeship-style training model, with the expectation that this experience will increase entry and retention of women in manufacturing jobs. Project findings may inform other STEM areas in which females and other groups are also underrepresented. The project may serve as a guide for evaluating project effectiveness in increasing participation of females and other underrepresented groups in manufacturing education and careers.

Owensboro Community and Technical College proposes to increase the number of underrepresented groups, particularly females, in manufacturing training programs and careers in the greater Owensboro region of western Kentucky. The primary audience will be underrepresented groups, particularly females, already employed in production positions. The project includes the following goals: 1) Expand current program offerings to provide manufacturing training to female students and other underrepresented groups; 2) Implement proven retention strategies to ensure students are successful (intensive advising, an early orientation program, instruction and mentoring from a manufacturing faculty with experience working with females and underrepresented groups, and facilitated discussions); 3) Incorporate proven techniques to recruit underrepresented groups, particularly females, in non-traditional fields (ambassadors/mentors, underrepresented groups depicted in marketing activities, and information sessions); 4) Host facilitated discussions with experts to create dialogue between schools, colleges, and employers that promote increased awareness, perceptions, and communication leading to greater gender diversity in the manufacturing industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes

The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project focused on increasing the number of underrepresented groups, particularly females, in manufacturing training programs and careers in the greater Owensboro region of western Kentucky. The primary target audience for this project included incumbent female workers employed in manufacturing production positions. Project objectives supporting this goal included:

  • Recruiting and enrolling 24 new students from underrepresented groups, particularly females, in a manufacturing program that leads to an associate degree in manufacturing.
  • Retaining at least 70% of these students through graduation with a two-year degree.
  • Sustaining the project and achieving a 40% enrollment of students from underrepresented groups, particularly females, in future cohorts.

To accomplish this, the project team developed and launched a work and learn program called GO Females, an acronym for Greater Owensboro Facilitating Equitable Manufacturing and Leadership Educational Solutions.

How it Works. GO Females is an associate degree program at Owensboro Community and Technical College (OCTC) that offers a solution for adults who need to maintain full-time employment while working toward a college credential. GO Females offers a hybrid format of online lectures and instructor-led, hands-on skill labs. These labs provide students with industry-relevant learning activities, assessments, skill mastery rubrics, and additional hands-on labs that incorporate real-world activities into the learning experience. Students spend at least eight hours of paid educational release time, during their work shift, each week in class at OCTC with the instructor. Other approaches utilized in the GO Females program involve:

  • Implementing retention strategies to ensure students are successful including intensive advising and success coaching, an early orientation program, instruction and mentoring from manufacturing faculty with industry experience, and ongoing facilitated discussions with students.
  • Incorporating techniques to recruit underrepresented groups, particularly females, in non-traditional fields including using mentors at the work site, depicting underrepresented groups in marketing materials and activities, and hosting multiple information sessions with prospective students.
  • Hosting events and facilitated discussions with employer and educational partners to promote increased awareness, perceptions, and communication leading to greater gender diversity in the manufacturing industry.

Results. The GO Females program led to the recruitment of more females to manufacturing programs and the progression of female production workers to skilled technician and/or leadership positions within their manufacturing employer. UniFirst Corporation in Owensboro, Kentucky, served as the employer champion for the first GO Females cohort of 20 female workers who began classes on October 21, 2019. UniFirst Corporation paid their employee participants full-time wages and benefits throughout the GO Females program and provided them eight hours of paid time off per week to attend classes. Fifteen of the students completed the program in July 2021 and earned a manufacturing associate degree from OCTC while working full-time. In addition to the first cohort of 20, six new GO Females students began classes at OCTC in fall 2021. These students are currently in a manufacturing pathway program and on track to earn an associate degree in May 2023.

Intellectual Merit. The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project is advancing knowledge and understanding in the manufacturing field by implementing model practices to recruit and retain females in manufacturing education programs and employment through using a proven, apprenticeship-style training strategy. The GO Female model is replicable in other STEM areas in which underrepresented groups, particularly females, do not participate historically.

Broader Impacts. The broader impact of this project includes the following:

  • Increasing participation of females in non-traditional careers and promoting diversity in the workforce.
  • Increasing partnerships between employers, educators, and other stakeholders to support the need for greater gender diversity and inclusion in the manufacturing industry and to transform workplace and education awareness, cultures, and practices for improved gender equality.
  • Developing a talent-driven pipeline of women in the manufacturing industry, which can only occur with the equal participation of genders in the workforce.
  • Developing a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce to address the skilled technician shortage in the manufacturing industry that, if not addressed, impacts the future economic health of Kentucky and the nation.
  • Sharing project best practices with employers, educators, industry, and workforce leaders across Kentucky and the nation, who are interested in increasing female participation in education and careers in manufacturing and other STEM areas.

The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project led to an emerging best practice to "skill up" female incumbent workers for advancement in the manufacturing industry. By engaging non-traditional populations, GO Females addresses the increasing need for skilled technicians and ensures that "no worker is left behind" in career and wage advancement opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: Sheri Plain

NSF Project Outcomes

The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project focused on increasing the number of underrepresented groups, particularly females, in manufacturing training programs and careers in the greater Owensboro region of western Kentucky. The primary target audience for this project included incumbent female workers employed in manufacturing production positions. Project objectives supporting this goal included:

Recruiting and enrolling 24 new students from underrepresented groups, particularly females, in a manufacturing program that leads to an associate degree in manufacturing.
Retaining at least 70% of these students through graduation with a two-year degree.
Sustaining the project and achieving a 40% enrollment of students from underrepresented groups, particularly females, in future cohorts.


To accomplish this, the project team developed and launched a work and learn program called GO Females, an acronym for Greater Owensboro Facilitating Equitable Manufacturing and Leadership Educational Solutions.

How it Works. GO Females is an associate degree program at Owensboro Community and Technical College (OCTC) that offers a solution for adults who need to maintain full-time employment while working toward a college credential. Students spend at least eight hours of paid educational release time, during their work shift, each week in class at OCTC with the instructor. Other approaches utilized in the GO Females program involve:

Implementing retention strategies to ensure      students are successful including intensive advising and success coaching,      an early orientation program, instruction and mentoring from manufacturing      faculty with industry experience, and ongoing facilitated discussions with      students.


Incorporating techniques to recruit      underrepresented groups, particularly females, in non-traditional fields including      using mentors at the work site, depicting underrepresented groups in      marketing materials and activities, and hosting multiple information      sessions with prospective students.


Hosting events and facilitated discussions      with employer and educational partners to promote increased awareness,      perceptions, and communication leading to greater gender diversity in the      manufacturing industry.


Results. The GO Females program led to the recruitment of more females to manufacturing programs and the progression of female production workers to skilled technician and/or leadership positions within their manufacturing employer. UniFirst Corporation in Owensboro, Kentucky, served as the employer champion for the first GO Females cohort of 20 female workers who began classes on October 21, 2019. Fifteen of the students completed the program in July 2021 and earned a manufacturing associate degree from OCTC while working full-time. In addition to the first cohort of 20, six new GO Females students began classes at OCTC in fall 2021. These students are currently in a manufacturing pathway program and on track to earn an associate degree in May 2023.

The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project is advancing knowledge and understanding in the manufacturing field by implementing model practices to recruit and retain females in manufacturing education programs and employment through using a proven, apprenticeship-style training strategy. The GO Female model is replicable in other STEM areas in which underrepresented groups, particularly females, do not participate historically.

Broader Impacts. The broader impact of this project includes the following:

Increasing participation of females in non-traditional careers and promoting diversity in the workforce.


Increasing partnerships between employers, educators, and other stakeholders to support the need for greater gender diversity and inclusion in the manufacturing industry and to transform workplace and education awareness, cultures, and practices for improved gender equality.


Developing a talent-driven pipeline of women in the manufacturing industry, which can only occur with the equal participation of genders in the workforce.


Developing a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce to address the skilled technician shortage in the manufacturing industry that, if not addressed, impacts the future economic health of Kentucky and the nation.


Sharing project best practices with employers, educators, industry, and workforce leaders across Kentucky and the nation, who are interested in increasing female participation in education and careers in manufacturing and other STEM areas.


The Advancing Female Incumbent Workers in the Manufacturing Industry (DUE-1903117) project led to an emerging best practice to "skill up" female incumbent workers for advancement in the manufacturing industry. By engaging non-traditional populations, GO Females addresses the increasing need for skilled technicians and ensures that "no worker is left behind" in career and wage advancement opportunities.
